data.title: Things to do in M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park
data.meta_description: There are four places that I consider a must-see in and around M√©rtola: The town of M√©rtola, of course, seat of the municipality on the banks of River Guadiana. The surreal Mina de S√£o Domingos,
data.text:
Sharing is caring!

There are four places that I consider a must-see in and around M√©rtola:

The town of M√©rtola, of course, seat of the municipality on the banks of River Guadiana.

The surreal Mina de S√£o Domingos, with its fabulous Tapada Grande river beach.

Pulo do Lobo, one of the most impressive spots along the Guadiana River in Portugal.

And the surroundings of Chan√ßa Dam, near Pomar√£o.

Do you want to discover each of these places? In this article I‚Äôll tell you all about what to do in M√©rtola and surroundings, so that you can make the most of the main landscapes that Guadiana Valley Natural Park has to offer.

This is still a largely unexplored region, a very different Portugal awaiting your visit!

Where is M√©rtola located, in Portugal?

M√©rtola is close to the border with Spain (Andalusia). To the south is the fabulous Algarve, where you‚Äôll find some of the best beaches in Portugal. To the north are Serpa and Beja. And finally, it also borders two of the municipalities on the mythical National Road 2: Castro Verde and Almod√¥var.

Guadiana Valley Natural Park has M√©rtola as its main entry point, so I can‚Äôt fail to mention it. It covers around 70000 hectares and stretches from Pulo do Lobo area (between Serpa and M√©rtola) to the mouth of Ribeira de Vasc√£o on River Guadiana, bordering the Algarve.

MORE ARTICLES FROM ALENTEJO AND ALGARVE: - Best Costa da Caparica beaches - Best beaches in Set√∫bal - Best Beaches in Sesimbra - Visit Ribeiro do Cavalo Beach - Best beaches in Tr√≥ia, Comporta and Melides - Best Beaches in Alentejo and Vicentine Coast - Things to do in Odemira and Vila Nova de Milfontes - Things to do in Marv√£o - Things to do in Elvas - Things to do in Estremoz - Things to do in Vila Vi√ßosa - Things to do in Monsaraz & Alqueva Lake - Things to do in Porto Covo and Sines - Things to do in Arraiolos - Best Things to do in √âvora and surroundings - Things to do in Beja - Algarve Road Trip Itinerary - Best Beaches in Algarve - Things to do in Sagres - Things to do in Lagos - Best Beaches in Lagos - Things to do in Portim√£o - Things to do in Arma√ß√£o de P√™ra and Silves - The Seven Hanging Valleys Trail - Best Beaches in Carvoeiro - Best Beaches in Albufeira - Things to do in Vilamoura and Quarteira - Things to do in Faro - Things to do in Tavira - Things to do in Olh√£o - Things to do in Monte Gordo

When to visit M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park?

Summer may not be the right time to visit M√©rtola, unless it‚Äôs a stopover point before or after a tour of the Algarve. The heat in summer is intense, and if you come at that time you‚Äôll only be fine at the Tapada Grande river beach in Mina de S√£o Domingos.

1. Producers‚Äô Market

Pay also attention to the region‚Äôs main festivities. The Producers‚Äô Market always takes place on the penultimate Saturday of each month, in the morning, in Rossio do Carmo square. It can be an excellent opportunity to get to know local products when you visit M√©rtola.

2. M√©rtola‚Äôs Gastronomic Events

T√∫bera Festival in March (a kind of fungus that is considered the ‚ÄúTruffle of the Alentejo‚Äù)

River Fish Festival in April

Hunting Fair in October, after all M√©rtola is the capital of hunting in Portugal.

Honey, Cheese and Bread Fair in April.

3. M√©rtola Islamic Festival

Here‚Äôs a link to M√©rtola Islamic Festival website, where you can find all the information you need about it. I think the theme is obvious, and the festival takes place every two years in May. This is perhaps the best time to visit M√©rtola!

4. M√©rtola Town Festivities

They take place in June at Cais do Guadiana, and end with a traditional ‚Äúsardinhada‚Äù (eating sardines).

5. M√©rtola Radical

A sports event that takes place in August with various activities in Serra de Alcaria, M√©rtola and Mina de S√£o Domingos (river beach).

How to get to M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park?

It is possible to reach M√©rtola by bus (Rede Expressos), from the main cities in the country, such as Lisbon.

However, M√©rtola is a very remote location in Alentejo, ideal for road trips, so my recommendation is that you rent a car, if you don‚Äôt have your own. Do it with Discover Cars, which allows you to compare several rental companies before finding the best deal! A car will give you a lot of flexibility when traveling in Alentejo.

Gastronomy and Restaurants in M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park

As this is the national capital of hunting, meat from hunting is the best option.

I didn‚Äôt try the T√∫beras, but they are also a possibility, as people say they are the truffle of the Alentejo.

And then there‚Äôs the typical Gaspacho, lamb stew, and Alentejo Migas.

For restaurants, I obviously recommend Espa√ßo Casa Amarela. As I‚Äôll also mention throughout the text that follows, this place has a great view of M√©rtola, and the food is even better. That‚Äôs where I had the pork cheeks in the photo below. Delicious!

Accommodation tips to visit M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park

Things to do in M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park

To visit M√©rtola and its surroundings, you‚Äôll need to pass through the historic center and then on to Pulo do Lobo, Pomar√£o and Mina de S√£o Domingos. I‚Äôm going to assume that your base of accommodation is M√©rtola, so I‚Äôll start by sharing what to visit in the town.

Map with things to do in M√©rtola

Visit the Historic Center of M√©rtola

The first tip is not to take the car into the historic center, as it‚Äôs not easy to drive in those narrow, sloping streets. My recommendation is that you visit the town of M√©rtola on foot, starting, for example, from places near Rossio do Carmo Square. That‚Äôs exactly what I did. From there I went up to the castle (the most touristy area), down to river Guadiana, and back up again at the end.

M√©rtola is in a place where remains of settlements dating back more than 5,000 years have been discovered. Various peoples settled there, long before the Arabs or even the Romans. In the Roman period it was Myrtilis and an important mercantile center, in the Arab period it was Martulah and the capital of an independent Arab emirate.

It was conquered from the Moors in the 13th century and from then on lost some of its importance in Portuguese territory. It gained new impetus, including population, with the start of mining in the 19th century, but half the population left the territory and never returned when the mines closed.

1. M√©rtola Municipal Market

The Tourist Office is right at the entrance to the walled town, shortly after you pass M√©rtola Municipal Market. Find out about the town‚Äôs museum and its opening hours there, as there are various sections around the town that you can visit.

2. Museum of M√©rtola

The House of M√©rtola and the Weaving Workshop are two parts of M√©rtola Museum, and are very close to the tourist office and the Mother Church. The first is a space that recreates a typical M√©rtola household in the mid-20th century, and the second shows you the artisanal process of weaving and decorating wool blankets in M√©rtola, with a clear Arab influence.

There are also other places to visit:

The Islamic Art Museum, with an exhibition of various archaeological remains found near M√©rtola that belong to the period of Arab occupation between the 9th and 13th centuries.

The Museum Center for Sacred Art, housed in the Church of Miseric√≥rdia. It exhibits sacred art objects (paintings and sculptures, for example), which have been removed from the region‚Äôs churches and stored in the museum for preservation.

The Roman House Museum, which gives access to the remains of a Roman house discovered in M√©rtola Town Hall building after a fire at the end of the 20th century.

The Museum Center of the Paleochristian Basilica. It is located in Rossio do Carmo and gives you access to the results of the archaeological excavation carried out there. They found traces of an ancient basilica that existed before the Moorish occupation, and several graves.

And the Blacksmith‚Äôs Forge Museum, which arose from the rehabilitation of the space where M√©rtola‚Äôs last blacksmith worked: ‚ÄúTi Brito‚Äôs Forge‚Äù. In this museum you can find all the tools he used in his daily life, arranged as they were in the past.

3. Mother Church of M√©rtola (Nossa Senhora da Assun√ß√£o)

Next up are the must-sees when visiting M√©rtola. I‚Äôll start with the Mother Church, which was an ancient mosque from the Islamic period, transformed into a church after the Christian reconquest. Visiting the museum section of the Mother Church of Nossa Senhora da Assun√ß√£o gives you access to information about the various phases of occupation of this place.

4. M√©rtola Castle

Due to its presence next to Guadiana river, M√©rtola has always been a point of communication between M√©rida and the Atlantic Ocean. Hence the need to defend and fortify it from an early age.

M√©rtola Castle arose during the Arab occupation, but its keep was already built after the Christian reconquest, by the Order of the Knights of Santiago.

5. M√©rtola‚Äôs Citadel

The remains of M√©rtola‚Äôs Citadel can be seen near the castle, and consist of the site where the Roman forum of M√©rtola was located and later an Islamic quarter. After the Christian reconquest, this site was converted into a cemetery, which helped preserve the archaeological remains, since nothing has appeared above the old buildings.

6. Calvary Chapel, Elias Garcia Street and M√©rtola Bridge

Next to the Calvary Chapel you have access to Rua Elias Garcia, which is perhaps the steepest street in M√©rtola! Believe me, you won‚Äôt want to do it the other way around! It‚Äôs an unmissable street, from where you have access to good viewpoints of M√©rtola Bridge.

In the middle of the street you‚Äôll find one of the aforementioned sections of M√©rtola Museum: the Blacksmith‚Äôs Forge. At the end of the street, in the lower part of the historic center, there are two others: the Museums of Sacred Art and Islamic Art.

7. Walls of M√©rtola, Guadiana Quay and River Tower

At the bottom of Rua Elias Garcia you will also find a dirt track that will take you to the Guadiana Quay, passing the ruins of the River Tower, also known as Coura√ßa Tower. This tower is thought to be part of the structure of an old bridge in M√©rtola, but it also had a defensive function and allowed safe access to the river for water supply.

8. M√©rtola Clock Tower

Once you reach the Guadiana pier, you‚Äôll find a path and staircase back to the historic center. It ends next to the Clock Tower, one of the most symbolic and photographed monuments in the town of M√©rtola.

9. Hotel Museu

On the outskirts of the historic center of M√©rtola there are still a few places to discover. One of them is Hotel Museum, a real hotel built on the banks of River Guadiana, above the ruins of an old Arab quarter. It has a museum center to visit, with all the pieces found when the hotel was built.

10. Cineteatro Marques Duque

Cineteatro Marques Duque is another tourist attraction in M√©rtola built on archaeological remains. Graves have been found there that are thought to belong to an extension of the cemetery of the Paleochristian basilica already mentioned.

11. Espa√ßo Casa Amarela and M√©rtola Viewpoint

Espa√ßo Casa Amarela is an excellent place to have lunch when visiting M√©rtola. In fact, this was one of the best restaurants I found while touring the Alentejo. Firstly, it has a privileged view of the town of M√©rtola from the other side of the river; and secondly, it serves delicious food. The black pork cheeks were so good that I devoured them in no time!

12. Azenhas do Guadiana River Beach

The name of Azenhas do Guadiana river beach comes from the watermills built by the Order of Santiago along the Guadiana river, with the aim of harnessing the power of the river to turn grain into flour.

If you wish, you can opt for boat trips from M√©rtola, which go as far as Alcoutim, in the Algarve, or Pomar√£o. You can also choose to rent a canoe and do a stretch of the river with it.

13. Chapel of Nossa Senhora das Neves

Finally, in M√©rtola, you must go up to the Chapel of Nossa Senhora das Neves, for another must-see viewpoint of the town.

Visit Pulo do Lobo and its walkways

Pulo do Lobo is north of M√©rtola and should be your next stop. It‚Äôs a great place for hiking when visiting the Guadiana Valley Natural Park.

I accessed the place from the bank where the Herdade do Pulo do Lobo gate is (which you have to open and close as you pass through). From that side it was easy to get to the rock formations and the waterfall, despite the dirt road. On the other side, however, it seems to me that you‚Äôll have access to the best views, which I also got with a drone. üòâ

More than the waterfall or the waters of the Guadiana river, what impressed me most was how the river has sculpted that rock into the most varied shapes: a true marvel!

Pulo do Lobo is a secluded spot which, despite being the most famous in the Guadiana Valley Natural Park, retains its wild side. Here you can experience nature at its purest and most untamed.

EDIT: Wooden walkways have recently been added to Pulo do Lobo!

Visit Pomar√£o and Chan√ßa Dam

Next to the Chan√ßa dam, climb up to the Pomar√£o Chapel for the best views of both the dam and Guadiana River in the south of the natural park. Half the dam is Portuguese, half Spanish!

At the end, walk down to the picturesque Pomar√£o pier.

Visit Mina de S√£o Domingos and Tapada Grande River Beach

To finish off your visit to M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park, there‚Äôs nothing better than the mining complex at Mina de S√£o Domingos. It‚Äôs like entering a parallel world!

With my car, I took to the dirt tracks and explored the ruins to the side of Achada do Gamo, for me the most spectacular area of the mines, with its intense colors and old, abandoned sulphur factories. Apocalyptic scenery!

But the best and safest way is to take a guided tour with the Serr√£o Martins Foundation. See their website for contact details.

There‚Äôs also the marked pedestrian route (PR10 ‚Äì Rota do Min√©rio), which takes you through the mining complex from Corta da Mina, through Moitinha Station, Achada do Gamo and finally the village of Santana de Cambas.

Don‚Äôt forget to visit what‚Äôs left of the ore wharf, the old railway workshops, the Miner‚Äôs House, the Church of S√£o Domingos, the English Garden, and of course, finish your visit with a dip in Tapada Grande river beach.

Mina de S√£o Domingos had its ore exploited in various historical periods, namely in the Roman period, the Islamic period and also during the 19th and 20th centuries. It was this last period of exploitation until 1966 that really transformed the landscape and left it looking so surreal. That, and of course, the vandalization and abandonment to which it was subjected from then on.

Millions of tons of ore were extracted from there! An entire village settled there because of the work in the mine. At its peak, more than 1,000 workers were employed there.

1. Corta da Mina de S√£o Domingos

It is a space resulting from open-pit mining in the 20th century, and reaches a depth of 120 meters. The water that accumulates there is highly acidic.

2. Malacate

It is an old iron structure whose purpose was to drain the water from the mine so that it would be possible to work dry inside.

3. Ore Wharf

This was the place where the ore was separated to be sent either to Moitinha or to other factories in Mina de S√£o Domingos, via one of the first railroad lines in the country. It could even be sent by wagon to the port of Pomor√£o, from where the ore was transported using River Guadiana.

4. Moitinha da Mina de S√£o Domingos

Moitinha was the place where the ore extracted from the mine was crushed.

5. Achada do Gamo

Achada do Gamo was the major intervention center for the ore extracted from the mine. Perhaps that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs my favorite place, the one that most marks the landscape. It was, however, the most damaging to the environment, mainly because of the fumes released by the sulphur furnaces.

6. Power Station

It was the first in the whole of the Alentejo, initially running on coal.

7. Railway Workshops of Mina de S√£o Domingos

It was where all the maintenance of the equipment needed to work in the mine was carried out. Today they are collapsing, and only part of their structure remains.

8. Miner‚Äôs House

The Miner‚Äôs House is part of M√©rtola Museum, but it is located in Mina de S√£o Domingos. In short, it is a replica of the house where a mining family lived in the 20th century. The mining families lived in a working class neighborhood, in small spaces and without much in the way of comfort.

9. Cineteatro da Mina de S√£o Domingos

Today it is an exhibition center on the history of the mining complex, but it was once a space dedicated to theater and cinema, available to the mining families who settled around the mine.

10. Church of S√£o Domingos

The village‚Äôs name of Mina de S√£o Domingos comes from the mine itself and also from the cult of Santo Domingo in the region. Although the church you see today is not the original one, nor the one that existed when the mine was being worked, it does represent this primitive hermitage.

11. English Garden

Today it is one of the village‚Äôs most beautiful green spaces, but it once represented the separation of social classes within the village. The English, who owned the mine (Mason & Barry), had their own neighborhood, with superior conditions and comfort compared to the mining families.

12. Tapada Grande River Beach

Finally, the river beach at Mina de S√£o Domingos. The beach is located on the largest of the reservoirs created in the village during the 19th century (Tapada Grande) to supply water to the mine. Today it is one of the best and most well-prepared river beaches in Alentejo, with good support: bar, toilets, parasols, picnic tables, parking and surveillance. It has a blue flag and a sandy beach or lawn where you can spread out your towel. It is also possible to rent a canoe for trips around the reservoir.

The Best Trails in Guadiana Valley Natural Park

As far as M√©rtola‚Äôs trails are concerned, I‚Äôve listed below what I consider to be the best routes in the municipality, with links to wikiloc.

PR1 ‚Äì Guadiana, the Great River of the South

A trail that starts from Po√ßo dos Dois Irm√£os, near the town of M√©rtola, and follows one of the banks of Guadiana River to the mouth of Ribeira de Carreiras. Along the way, you‚Äôll pass the Old Convent of S√£o Francisco.

It‚Äôs about 10km round trip. I only recommend this trail as one of the best in Guadiana Valley Natural Park because of its proximity to the river. My real favorites are the next ones.

Link to wikiloc.

PR9 ‚Äì Between Escalda and Pulo do Lobo

A trail near the fabulous Pulo do Lobo. If you prefer, just do the stage along River Guadiana, from Pulo do Lobo to Escalda Mill. It‚Äôs about 6 km long. If you do it in its entirety, you‚Äôll be able to see Pias Dolmen, a megalithic monument in Guadiana Valley Natural Park.

Link to wikiloc

PR10 ‚Äì Ore Route at Mina de S√£o Domingos

A 17km trail that runs through the mining heritage of Mina de S√£o Domingos, already mentioned in this article. For me, it‚Äôs the most interesting trail on this list. There is also the possibility of a guided tour.

Link to wikiloc

I hope you enjoyed this article with things to do in M√©rtola and Guadiana Valley Natural Park. Have a nice time in my country! üòâ

Sharing is caring!
